awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Compact Data Structures for String Matching and Retrieval
awd_abstract_narration:
In the era of big-data, one needs to organize massive amounts of data 
so that it can be searched quickly. This requires the building of an 
index over the raw data. In many cases of big-data, like world-wide web
or DNA sequencing, the actual information content is low. This data is 
highly compressible. On the other hand, the indexes require space which 
is several times the raw data. Thus, indexing and compression are often 
conflicting goals. The field of compact (or succinct) data structures 
attempts to achieve both these goals -compression and indexability- 
simultaneously. This project will address some of the most fundamental 
open problems in this field. This will have impact on next generation 
biological sequence mining databases which could simply work within the 
memory of a PC instead of requiring high-performance clusters. The 
foundations built by this project will also impact image matching and 
music retrieval. Since data structures is one of the most fundamental 
areas in computer science education, research from this project will 
also impact data structures curriculum.

Suffix trees are central to string indexing and have myriads of 
applications. However, suffix trees are known to take 15 to 50 times 
the size of the text they index. This actually stems from a complexity 
gap in the size of data which is n log s bits compared to the size of 
the index which is O( n log n) bits, for the text of n characters drawn 
from alphabet size of s. The techniques of Burrows-Wheeler Transform(BWT)
and Phi-function were introduced in the last decade to address this gap. 
Most subsequent research in this field has treated BWT as a black box, 
compressing augmenting structures around it to address various 
applications. However, many problems (like parameterized pattern matching
and 2D pattern matching) have remained open in this field. This project 
will attempt to go deeper and beyond the philosophy of BWT to solve such 
issues. It will also try to build foundations for deriving lower bounds 
for problems where compact index would be impossible. To create better 
understanding of data structure space and query complexity, the project 
will explore the recent theoretical model called "encoding  model". The 
project will also explore the applied case of compressed indexing for 
highly repetitive sequences.

For further information see the project web site at:  
http://csc.lsu.edu/~rahul/succinct
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to develop compressed indexing data structures for some pattern matching variant which were known to evade the attempts so far. We also envisioned that such a pursuit will lead to new tools and techniques on upper bounds as well as lower bound side for the problems. in turn, bringing newer insights and tools and techniques to the overall field of compressed text indexing. Specifically, we focussed on three problems: (1) Parameterized pattern matching (2) Order-Isomorphic Pattern matching (3) 2-dimensional pattern matching.We list here, the major results we obtained in each of these three dierections:

(1) We developed the first known succinct index with O(n log s) space which can answer pattern matching and Suffix Array queries in polylogarithmic time. [SODA 2017]. We further extended our results to make it fully funcational parameterized suffix trees. [ICALP 2022]

(2) We designed first known compact index for Order-isomorphic pattern matching. We achieved this via a novel technique of using LF-successor. [ICALP 2021]

(3) For 2D pattern matching, while the main result of achieving suffix array queries in polylogarithmic time and compact space still evades us, we showed that inverse suffix array queries can be answered in near compact space. [ISAAC 2021]

Two graudate students were largely funded by this project. We also conducted activities involving elementary and middle school students.


Last Modified: 07/11/2022
Modified by: Rahul T Shah
